answers.author: Silas Clarke
answers.text:
I think your question is thought provoking and something that needs a larger conversation.  I was hoping Jack Butler's question "Reconsideration of guidelines on Tenet 7" a few months ago was going to make that happen.  If the link works it can be found here http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/question/21400 or you can search for the topic with the title above.
Tenet 7 reads:
Refrain from all political activities which undermine public confidence in professional administrators.  Refrain from participation in the election of the members of the employing legislative body.
So I guess to answer your question with a question:
Do you believe your attendance will "undermine public confidence in professional administrators?"  
Good luck; I came from a politically appointed position and have struggled with Tenet 7 as well since being a City Administrator.  It has been difficult in some situations.
Silas

answers.author: Jared Dailey
answers.text:
I advise that you do not attend this event. Because the event is sponsored by the candidate, by attending, you would be showing public support for this particular candidate. Tenet 7 and specifically the Elections Guideline, prohibits members from showing public support for candidates seeking elected office. This prohibition includes yard signs, bumper stickers, signing nominating petitions, and providing financial contributions as well as running for office yourself.
You are encouraged to vote for the candidate(s) of your choice but that's where your 'support' for candidates should stop as an in-service member. You may risk an ethics inquiry if you do attend.
Please feel free to contact me if you would like to discuss this matter or Tenet 7 in further detail.

answers.author: Toby Cotter
answers.text:
Developing friendships with elected officials in our profession is rather easy. Telling a friend that you cannot attend the election party is hard, but essential to our profession. We all want to share in the joy of seeing friends celebrate, but a city manager must never see the streamers or drink the sparkling wine at an election night party.

author: [Anonymous]
text: Is it a violation of ethics to attend an election night watch party, hosted by a county commissioner up for re-election.  Background: he and I are close, personal friends (over 20 years); I have not campaigned for him - even though I live in his district (not even a yard sign); I am a CA in a city within the same county.  I am a friend and constituent, but do not want to compromise my ICMA ethical pledge.  Comments or suggestions?  Thanks.
title: City Administrator
